Confined Gradient Descent: Privacy-preserving Optimization for Federated Learning

Yanjun Zhang 0001-5611-3483 The University of QueenslandSt LuciaQueenslandAustralia4067 yanjun.zhang@uq.edu.au ,Â  Guangdong Bai The University of QueenslandSt LuciaQueenslandAustralia4067 g.bai@uq.edu.au ,Â  Xue Li The University of QueenslandSt LuciaQueenslandAustralia4067 xueli@itee.uq.edu.au ,Â  Surya Nepal Data61 CSIRO AustraliaMARSFIELDNew South WalesAustralia2122 Surya.Nepal@data61.csiro.au Â andÂ  Ryan K L Ko The University of QueenslandSt LuciaQueenslandAustralia4067 ryan.ko@uq.edu.au
Abstract.

Federated learning enables multiple participants to collaboratively train a model without aggregating the training data. Although the training data are kept within each participant and the local gradients can be securely synthesized, recent studies have shown that such privacy protection is insufficient. The global model parameters that have to be shared for optimization are susceptible to leak information about training data. In this work, we propose Confined Gradient Descent (CGD) that enhances privacy of federated learning by eliminating the sharing of global model parameters. CGD exploits the fact that a gradient descent optimization can start with a set of discrete points and converges to another set at the neighborhood of the global minimum of the objective function. It lets the participants independently train on their local data, and securely share the sum of local gradients to benefit each other. We formally demonstrate CGD â€™s privacy enhancement over traditional FL. We prove that less information is exposed in CGD compared to that of traditional FL. CGD also guarantees desired model accuracy. We theoretically establish a convergence rate for CGD. We prove that the loss of the proprietary models learned for each participant against a model learned by aggregated training data is bounded. Extensive experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate the performance of CGD is comparable with the centralized learning, with marginal differences on validation lossÂ (mostly within 0.05) and accuracyÂ (mostly within 1%).

1. Introduction

The performance of machine learning largely relies on the availability of large representative datasets. To take advantage of massive data owned by multiple entities, federated learning (FL) is proposedÂ (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016b; Yang etÂ al., 2019; KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016a). It enables participants to jointly train a global model without the necessity of sharing their datasets, demonstrating the potential to address the issues of data privacy and data ownership. It has been incorporated by popular machine learning tools such as TensorFlowÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016a) and PyTorchÂ (Paszke etÂ al., 2019), and increasingly spread over various industries.

The privacy preservation of FL stems from its parallelization of the gradient descent optimization, which in essence is an application of stochastic gradient descent (SGD)Â (or the mini-batch mode)Â (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016b). During the training process, the participants work on the same intermediate global model via a coordinating serverÂ (in the centralized FL)Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Abadi etÂ al., 2016b) or a peer-to-peer communication schemeÂ (in the decentralized FL)Â (Kim etÂ al., 2019; Roy etÂ al., 2019). Each of them obtains the current model parameters, works out a local gradient based on the local data, and disseminates it to update the global model synchronouslyÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016b; Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) or asynchronouslyÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2019). This paradigm guarantees data locality, but has been found insufficient for data privacy: although the local gradients can be securely synthesized via a variety of techniques such as differential privacy (DP)Â (Abadi etÂ al., 2016b; Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; Hu etÂ al., 2019; Zhang etÂ al., 2020b), secure multi-party communication (MPC)Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; GascÃ³n etÂ al., 2017), and homomorphic encryption (HE)Â (Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Marc etÂ al., 2019; Sharma and Chen, 2019), the global model parameters that have to be shared are still susceptible to information leakage(cf. Section 5 andÂ (Papernot etÂ al., 2018; Nasr etÂ al., 2019)).

This work further decreases the dependency among participants by eliminating the explicit sharing of the central global model which is the root cause of the information leakageÂ (Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015; Nasr etÂ al., 2019). We propose a new optimization algorithm named Confined Gradient Descent (CGD) that enables each participant to learn a proprietary global model. The CGD participants maintain their global models locally, which are strictly confined within themselves from the beginning of and throughout the whole training process. We refer to these localized global models as confined models, to distinguish them from the global model in traditional FL.

CGD is inspired by an observation on the surface of the typical cost function. The steepness of the first derivative decreases slower when approaching the minimum of the function, due to the small values in the Hessian (i.e., the second derivative) near the optimumÂ (Bottou, 2012). This gives the function, when plotted, a flat valley bottom. As such, a gradient descent algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, when applied on an objective function Fğ¹F, could start with a set of discrete points (referred to as a colony and their distance is discussed later). Iteratively descending the colony using the joint gradient of the colony would lead ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} to the neighborhood of Fğ¹Fâ€™s minimum in the â€œflat valley bottomâ€. The points in the colony would also end up with similar losses that are close to the loss of the minimum.

In FigureÂ 1, we illustrate a holistic comparison between the workflow of CGD and that of a gradient decent in traditional FL. In traditional FL, every participant updates the same global model wğ‘¤w using their local gradients ga,gb,gcsuperscriptğ‘”ğ‘superscriptğ‘”ğ‘superscriptğ‘”ğ‘g^{a},g^{b},g^{c}. In CGD, each participant lğ‘™l first independently initializes the starting point of its confined model w1lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘™w_{1}^{l}. Then, in every training iteration, participants independently compute the local gradient from their current confined model and local data, and then jointly work out the sum of all local gradients and use it to update their confined modelsÂ (the equation in Figure 1b). By doing this, CGD aims to enhance privacy without sacrificing much model accuracy. For the sake of simplicity, we refer to these two properties as privacy and accuracy.

  • â€¢

    Privacy. CGD should ensure that, throughout the training process, neither local data of a participant nor intermediate results computed on them can be observed by other participants or an aggregatorÂ (if any).

  • â€¢

    Accuracy. The prediction made by any confined model should approach the centralized model that were to learn centrally on the gathered data.

The desired privacy enhancement of CGD stems from two aspects, i.e., secrecy of confined models and secrecy of local gradients. For the former, besides always hiding the confined models from each other, each participant independently initializes its w1lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘™w_{1}^{l} at random. During the training process, any two confined models keep the same distance and never become closer to each other after descending, preventing any participant from predicting models of others. To further boost the unpredictability, each participant could select its own interval range of initial weights to avoid leaking the average distance between the confined models. CGD withstands interval ranges differing by two orders of magnitude. For the latter, CGD incorporates the secure addition operation on the local gradients to calculate their sum. This has been proved to be viable through the additive secret sharing scheme, in which the sum of a set of secret values is collaboratively calculated without revealing any addendsÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bogdanov etÂ al., 2008; Lin and Tzeng, 2005; Tebaa etÂ al., 2012). A previous studyÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2020a) demonstrates it is efficient when applied to achieve decentralization in FL. We prove that the adversaryâ€™s observation in CGD is only the sum of local gradients, and it conceals the extra indicative information that traditional FL would leakÂ (cf. SectionÂ 5).

We formally prove that CGD ensures convergence. It converges to confined models that are adjacent to the centralized model, and the adjacency is boundedÂ (cf. SectionÂ 4). This merit guarantees the accuracy of CGD. We further evaluate the accuracy performance of CGD with two popular benchmark datasets, i.e., MNISTÂ (LeCun and Cortes, 2010) and CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009). Our experiments demonstrate that its accuracy closely approaches that of the centralized learning. When the confined models are initialized with the standard initialization schemeÂ (i.e., the Gaussian distribution of mean 0 and the variance 1), it achieves marginal differences on validation loss Â (mostly within 0.05) and accuracyÂ (mostly within 1%) and outperforms state-of-the-art federated learning with differential privacy. Its accuracy performance remains stable even when the interval ranges of initial weights among participants differ by two orders of magnitude.

Contributions

We summarize the main contributions as follows.

  • â€¢

    Confined Gradient Descent For Privacy-enhancing Decentralized Federated Learning. We propose a new optimization algorithm CGD for privacy-preserving decentralized FL. CGD eliminates the explicit sharing of the global model and lets each participant learn a proprietary confined model. CGD retains the merits of traditional FL such as algorithm independence. Therefore, it can easily accommodate any FL schemes regardless of their underlying machine/deep learning algorithms. It also eliminates the necessity of a central coordinating server, such that the optimization can be conducted in a fully decentralized manner.

  • â€¢

    Convergence Analysis. We theoretically establish a convergence rate for CGD under realistic assumptions on the loss function (such as convexity). We prove CGD converges toward the centralized model as the number of iterations increases. The distance between the trained confined models and the centralized model is bounded, and can be tuned by the hyper-parameter setting.

  • â€¢

    Enhanced Privacy Preservation Over Traditional FL. With secrecy of both confined model and local gradients, CGD achieves enhanced privacy preservation over traditional FL. We prove that in CGD, given only the sum of the local gradients, an honest-but-curious white-box adversary, who may control tğ‘¡t out of mğ‘šm participantsÂ (where tâ‰¤mâˆ’2ğ‘¡ğ‘š2t\leq m-2) including the aggregator for secure addition operationÂ (if any), can learn no information other than their own inputs and the sum of the local gradients from other honest parties, whereas in traditional FL, extra indicative information about local data can be obtained.

  • â€¢

    Functional Evaluations. We implement CGD and conduct experiments on two popular benchmark datasets MNIST and CIFAR-10. The results demonstrate that CGD can closely approach the performance of centralized model on the validation loss and accuracy, with marginal differences on validation loss Â (mostly within 0.05) and accuracyÂ (mostly within 1%).

2. Background and Related Works

CGD is an optimization method based on the gradient decent. Therefore, in this section, we review the existing techniques for gradient updates in the traditional FL.

2.1. Stochastic gradient descent

Stochastic gradient descentÂ (SGD)Â (Robbins and Monro, 1951; Bottou etÂ al., 2018) is an efficient variant of the gradient descent algorithm. It is extensively used for optimizing the objective function in machine learning and deep learning. Given a cost function Fğ¹F with the parameter wğ‘¤w, SGD is defined by

The gradients, if shared in plain text, are subject to information leakage of the local training data. For example, model-inversion attacksÂ (Melis etÂ al., 2019; Fredrikson etÂ al., 2015; Shokri etÂ al., 2017) are able to restore training data from the gradients. In the immediately following sections, we summarize the existing privacy-preserving methods for synthesizing the local gradients, which fall into two broad categories, i.e., secure aggregation and learning with differential privacy.

2.2. Secure aggregation

Secure aggregation typically employs cryptographic mechanisms such as homomorphic encryption (HE)Â (Chen etÂ al., 2018; Marc etÂ al., 2019; Sharma and Chen, 2019) and/or secure multiparty computation (MPC)Â (GascÃ³n etÂ al., 2017, 2016; Liu etÂ al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Zhang etÂ al., 2020a) to securely evaluate the gradient âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wk,Î¾l,k)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘™ğ‘˜\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k}) without revealing local data. With âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wk,Î¾l,k)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘™ğ‘˜\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k}), all the participants can thus take a gradient descent step by EquationÂ 2.

Some existing studies fall into this category. For instance, Bonawitz et al. Â (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017) present a secure aggregation protocol that allows a server to compute the sum of user-held data vectors, which can be used to aggregate user-provided model updates for a deep neural network. Mohassel et al.Â (Mohassel and Zhang, 2017) propose a secure two-party computation (2PC) protocol that supports secure arithmetic operations on shared decimal numbers for calculating the gradient updates using SGD.

Existing FL frameworks employing HE/MPC are mainly based on federated SGD. All the participants in it share and update one and the same global model, and this is subject to membership inference, as revealed by Nasr et al.Â (Nasr etÂ al., 2019).

2.3. Learning with differential privacy

Another line of studies that approaches to privacy-preserving FL is through differential privacy (DP) mechanismÂ (Zheng etÂ al., 2019; Hagestedt etÂ al., 2019; Abadi etÂ al., 2016b; Song etÂ al., 2013; Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; Dwork etÂ al., 2014; Hu etÂ al., 2019; Zhang etÂ al., 2020b; Geyer etÂ al., 2017). The common practice of achieving differential privacy is based on additive noise calibrated to âˆ‡Fâˆ‡ğ¹\nabla Fâ€™s sensitivity ğ’®âˆ‡F2subscriptsuperscriptğ’®2âˆ‡ğ¹\mathcal{S}^{2}_{\nabla F}. As such, a differentially private learning framework can be achieved by updating parameters with perturbed gradients at each iteration, for example, to update parameters as

The privacy loss is accumulated with repeated access to the data during training epochsÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016b). There is also an inherent tradeoff between privacy and utility of the trained model.

In summary, in all of the above approaches, the global model has to be shared with each participant, leading to the leakage of information. This motivates CGDâ€™s design to eliminate the explicit sharing of the central global model.

3. Confined Gradient Descent

CGD optimizes an objective function in FL with multiple local datasets. It starts with a colony of discrete points, and then uses the combination of their gradients to lead the optimization to another colony of points at the neighborhood of the global optimum. In this section, we formalize this problem and present the workflow of CGD optimization.

3.1. Problem formulation

This is reduced to solving the following problem

3.2. CGD optimization

Figure 2 illustrates the architecture of CGD (Figure 2c), with a comparison to the centralized trainingÂ (Figure 2a) and traditional FLÂ (Figure 2b). In the centralized training, the datasets of all participants are gathered for training a single model. In the traditional FL, every participant owns its local training dataset, and updates the same global model wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} via a parameter server using its local model/gradients. The local gradients âˆ‡Fâ€‹(wk,Î¾l,k)âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘™ğ‘˜\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k}) can be protected via either secure aggregationÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Zhang etÂ al., 2020a; Marc etÂ al., 2019; Sharma and Chen, 2019; Liu etÂ al., 2017) or differential privacy mechanismsÂ (Abadi etÂ al., 2016b; Song etÂ al., 2013; Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; Dwork etÂ al., 2014; Hu etÂ al., 2019; Zhang etÂ al., 2020b). This process can be decentralized by replacing the parameter server with a peer-to-peer communication mechanismÂ (Kim etÂ al., 2019; Roy etÂ al., 2019). In CGD, each participant learns its own confined modelÂ (represented by different colors), i.e., each wklsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘™ğ‘˜w^{l}_{k} is different and private. The model updating in CGD synthesizes the information from all training samples by summing up the local gradients, while in federated SGDÂ (Figure 2b), each iteration takes into account only a subset of training samples.

To better position CGD, we summarize the related studies in the literature in TableÂ 1. We use federated SGD to represent the SGD or the mini-batch update in the FL, including both the plain SGD in which the local gradient/model is shared in plaintext, and privacy-preserving SGD via secure aggregation or differential privacy mechanisms. CGD guarantees that each confined model, when CGD converges, is at the neighborhood of the centralized model, retaining the model accuracy (column 5 in Table 1 and proved in Section 4). It also achieves desired privacy preservation compared to the traditional FL (column 6 in Table 1 and detailed in Section 5).

4. Convergence Analysis

In this section, we conduct a formal convergence analysis on CGD. Convergence analysis has been extensively used in the literatureÂ (Hu etÂ al., 2019; Hsieh etÂ al., 2017; Ho etÂ al., 2013) to prove the correctness of optimization algorithms. Through the analysis, we demonstrate the bound of the distance between an arbitrary wâˆ—lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘™w_{*}^{l} learned by CGD and the centralized model wâˆ—subscriptğ‘¤w_{*}. The analysis is centered around a regret function â„›â„›\mathcal{R}, which is the difference between the CGDâ€™s training loss and the loss of the centralized model, defined as

4.1. Assumptions

We make the following assumptions on the loss function Fğ¹F. They all are common assumptions in convergence analyses of most gradient-based methods, and satisfied in a variety of widely used cost functionsÂ (Bottou etÂ al., 2018), such as mean squared error (MSE) and cross entropy.

Assumption 1.

(Lipschitz continuity). The loss function Fğ¹F: â„dâ†’â„â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is continuously differentiable and the gradient function of Fğ¹F, namely, âˆ‡Fâˆ‡ğ¹\nabla F: â„dâ†’â„dâ†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d}, is Lipschitz continuous with Lipschitz constant L>0ğ¿0L>0,

(7) â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(w)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(w^)â€–2â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–wâˆ’w^â€–2â€‹Â for allÂ â€‹{w,w^}âŠ‚â„d.subscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¤âˆ‡ğ¹^ğ‘¤2ğ¿subscriptnormğ‘¤^ğ‘¤2Â for allÂ ğ‘¤^ğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\|\nabla F(w)-\nabla F(\widehat{w})\|_{2}\leq L\|w-\widehat{w}\|_{2}\text{\quad for all }\{w,\widehat{w}\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Intuitively, this assumption ensures that the gradient of Fğ¹F does not change arbitrarily in the course of descending, such that the gradient can be a proper indicator towards the optimumÂ (Bottou etÂ al., 2018).

Assumption 2.

(Strong convexity). The loss function Fğ¹F: â„dâ†’â„â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is strongly convex such that

(8) Fâ€‹(w^)â‰¥Fâ€‹(w)+âˆ‡Fâ€‹(w)Tâ€‹(w^âˆ’w)â€‹Â for allÂ â€‹{w,w^}âŠ‚â„d.ğ¹^ğ‘¤ğ¹ğ‘¤âˆ‡ğ¹superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘‡^ğ‘¤ğ‘¤Â for allÂ ğ‘¤^ğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘F(\widehat{w})\geq F(w)+\nabla F(w)^{T}(\widehat{w}-w)\text{\quad for all }\{w,\widehat{w}\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}.

A useful fact from Assumption 2 for our analysis is

(9) (Fâ€‹(w)âˆ’Fâ€‹(wâˆ—))â‰¤âŸ¨wâˆ’wâˆ—,âˆ‡Fâ€‹(w)âŸ©â€‹Â for allÂ â€‹wâŠ‚â„d,ğ¹ğ‘¤ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¤âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¤Â for allÂ ğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘(F(w)-F(w_{*}))\leq\langle w-w_{*},\nabla F(w)\rangle\text{\quad for all }w\subset\mathbb{R}^{d},

where âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ©â‹…â‹…\langle\cdot{,}\cdot\rangle denotes the inner product operation.

In addition, we adopt the same assumption on a bounded solution space used in related studiesÂ (Bottou etÂ al., 2018; Hu etÂ al., 2019).

Assumption 3.

(Bounded solution space). The set of {wkl}|kâˆˆ[1,T]evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘™ğ‘˜1ğ‘‡\{w_{k}^{l}\}|_{k\in[1,T]} is contained in an open set over which Fğ¹F is bounded below a scalar Fiâ€‹nâ€‹fsubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘“F_{inf}, such that

  1. (a)

    there exists a D>0ğ·0D>0, s.t., â€–wklâˆ’wâˆ—â€–22â‰¤D2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¤22superscriptğ·2\|w_{k}^{l}-w_{*}\|_{2}^{2}\leq D^{2} for all kğ‘˜k, and

  2. (b)

    there exists a G>0ğº0G>0, s.t., â€–glâ€‹(wkl,Î¾l)â€–22â‰¤G2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptğ‘”ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptğœ‰ğ‘™22superscriptğº2\|g^{l}(w_{k}^{l},\xi_{l})\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2} for all wklâŠ‚â„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w_{k}^{l}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}.

4.2. Main Theorem

We first present our main theorem below, and leave its proof to SectionÂ 4.3. It demonstrates our main result on the converge rate of CGD.

Theorem 1.

Given a cost function satisfying Assumptions 1 - 3, and a learning rate of Î±k=Î±(k+Î¼â€‹T)2subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ›¼superscriptğ‘˜ğœ‡ğ‘‡2\alpha_{k}=\frac{\alpha}{(k+\mu T)^{2}} (0<Î¼<10ğœ‡10<\mu<1), the CGD optimization gives the regret â„›â„›\mathcal{R}

(10) â„›=Oâ€‹(Ïµ+1Î¼â€‹T+1+lnâ¡|Î¼â€‹T+1|T)â„›ğ‘‚italic-Ïµ1ğœ‡ğ‘‡1ğœ‡ğ‘‡1ğ‘‡\mathcal{R}=O(\epsilon+\frac{1}{\mu T+1}+\frac{\ln|\mu T+1|}{T})

where Ïµ=mâ€‹â€–ğ”¼jâˆˆm(w1lâˆ’w1j)â€–italic-Ïµğ‘šnormsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘—ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘—\epsilon=m\|\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{j\in m}(w_{1}^{l}-w_{1}^{j})\|.

The theorem implies the following two remarks.

  • â€¢

    Convergence rate. Both 1Î¼â€‹T+11ğœ‡ğ‘‡1\frac{1}{\mu T+1} and lnâ¡|Î¼â€‹T+1|Tğœ‡ğ‘‡1ğ‘‡\frac{\ln|\mu T+1|}{T} approach 0 as Tğ‘‡T increases, implying that CGD will converge toward the optimum. The convergence rate can be adjusted by the parameter Î¼ğœ‡\muÂ (the effect of Î¼ğœ‡\mu is investigated in Section 7.2.2).

  • â€¢

    Bounded optimality gap. When CGD converges, the gap between the confined models and the centralized model is bounded by Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. CGD uses the initialization parameter Î´lsuperscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta^{l} to determine the range of w1lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘™w_{1}^{l} in the way of

    (11) w1l=Î´lâ‹…ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘lâ€‹Â for allÂ â€‹lâˆˆ(1,m),superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘™â‹…superscriptğ›¿ğ‘™superscriptğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘™Â for allÂ ğ‘™1ğ‘šw_{1}^{l}=\delta^{l}\cdot\mathit{Rand}^{l}\text{\quad for all }l\in(1,m),

    where ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘\mathit{Rand} is the initialization scheme. A standard ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘\mathit{Rand} used in machine learning is to apply random sampling from the Gaussian distribution of mean 0 and the variance 1, and a standard Î´ğ›¿\delta is 1n1ğ‘›\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} (where nğ‘›n is the sample size)Â (Glorot and Bengio, 2010). In CGD, each participant determines its own ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘lsuperscriptğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘™\mathit{Rand}^{l} and Î´lsuperscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta^{l} independently to avoid leaking the average distance among the confined models. Our experiment finds that CGD keeps robustÂ (in terms of validation accuracy) even when the participants select their Î´lsuperscriptğ›¿ğ‘™\delta^{l}s uniformly at random in a range of (10n,0.1n)10ğ‘›0.1ğ‘›(\frac{10}{\sqrt{n}},\frac{0.1}{\sqrt{n}}) (cf. Section 7.2.1).

5. Privacy Preservation

The participants in CGD have to share the sum of local gradients, i.e., âˆ‘j=1mgjâ€‹(wkj,Î¾j)superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘”ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘—\sum\limits_{j=1}^{m}g^{j}(w^{j}_{k},\xi_{j}). A straightforward way is to let each participant release its local gradient glâ€‹(wkl,Î¾l)superscriptğ‘”ğ‘™subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘™ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘™g^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l}), but it may leak information about Î¾lsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘™\xi_{l} or wklsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘™ğ‘˜w^{l}_{k}Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2020a). To address this, we incorporate the secure addition operationÂ (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017; Bogdanov etÂ al., 2008; Lin and Tzeng, 2005; Tebaa etÂ al., 2012) on the local gradients to calculate their sum without releasing each of them. We make use of the additive secret sharing scheme proposed by Bogdanov et al.Â (Bogdanov etÂ al., 2008), which uses additive sharing over â„¤232subscriptâ„¤superscript232\mathbb{Z}_{2^{32}} for securely evaluating addition operations in a multiparty computation environment. It guarantees the secrecy of the addends even though the majority (mâˆ’2ğ‘š2m-2 out of mğ‘šm) of participants are compromised. An brief introduction of the additive secret sharing scheme can be found in Appendix A.

In the rest of this section, we explore the privacy preservation of CGD. We demonstrate CGDâ€™s privacy enhancement over traditional FL. We prove that less information is exposed in CGD compared to that of traditional FL.

5.1. Information exposed in CGD

Recall that the involved parties are a set â„’â„’\mathcal{L} of mğ‘šm participants denoted with logical identities lâˆˆ[1,m]ğ‘™1ğ‘šl\in[1,m], and tğ‘¡t is the adversarial threshold (tâ‰¤mâˆ’2ğ‘¡ğ‘š2t\leq m-2) (Section 3.1.2). Let cğ‘c be any subset of â„’â„’\mathcal{L} that includes the compromised and colluding parties.

We demonstrate that, during optimization in CGD, given only the sum of the local gradients which are computed on different confined models, the adversary can learn no information other than their own inputs and the sum of the local gradients from other honest parties, i.e., âˆ‘gklâ€‹(wkl,Î¾l)âˆ£lâˆˆâ„’âˆ–cevaluated-atsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜ğ‘™subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘™ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘™ğ‘™â„’ğ‘\sum g_{k}^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l})\mid_{l\in\mathcal{L}\setminus c}.

Our analysis is based on the simulation paradigmÂ (Goldreich etÂ al., 2019). It compares what an adversary can do in a real protocol execution to what it can do in an ideal scenario, which is secure by definition. The adversary in the ideal scenario, is called the simulator. An indistinguishability between adversaryâ€™s view in real and ideal scenarios guarantees that it can learn nothing more than their own inputs and the information required by the simulator for the simulation. A brief introduction of the simulation paradigm is given in Appendix B.

To facilitate the understanding on our analysis, we first present the used notations. Differentially private federated SGD

In most differentially private federated SGD, the local gradients are protected by additive noise mechanism as

(40) wk+1â†wkâˆ’Î±kâ€‹(gklâ€‹(wk,Î¾l)+ğ’©k),â†subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‰ğ‘™subscriptğ’©ğ‘˜w_{k+1}\leftarrow w_{k}-\alpha_{k}(g^{l}_{k}(w_{k},\xi_{l})+\mathcal{N}_{k}),

where ğ’©ksubscriptğ’©ğ‘˜\mathcal{N}_{k} denote the noise added at the ktâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¡â„k^{th} iteration. By combing Equation 35, it can be written as

(41) wk+1â†wkâˆ’Î±kâ€‹(xlTâ€‹Î”â€‹(xlâ€‹wk,yl)+ğ’©k),â†subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘‡Î”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘™subscriptğ’©ğ‘˜w_{k+1}\leftarrow w_{k}-\alpha_{k}(x_{l}^{T}\Delta(x_{l}w_{k},y_{l})+\mathcal{N}_{k}),

However, with repeated access to the datasets during training epochs, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon (the parameter of privacy loss) accumulates, i.e., privacy degrades, as the effect of added noise being canceled outÂ (Dwork etÂ al., 2014; Abadi etÂ al., 2016b).

5.3. Enhanced privacy over traditional FL

Traditional FL requires all participants to update the same global model during the training process. Every participant thus sees the identical intermediate results, as the same aggregated gradients are shared. This is the root cause of most privacy threats against FL. CGD breaks the mode of single global model, by introducing random variation among the proprietary global models of the participants. The variation hides each global model from other participants, such that the privacy is enhanced in general.

In Table 2, we summarize the privacy enhancement from the perspective of adversaryâ€™s observation, i.e, the exposed information to the adversary during the optimization. In traditional FL, the sharing of global model wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k}, even if the local gradients are protected, is still subject to information leakage about the original dataset. By eliminating the sharing of wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} and letting each participant confine its own wklsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘™w_{k}^{l}, CGD achieves boosted privacy over traditional privacy-preserving FL. (1) Compared to secure aggregated FL in which indicative information about original datasets can be observed via the sharing of wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} (Theorem 2), the variation among wklsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘™w_{k}^{l} in CGD prevents such information from disclosure, and guarantees that only the sum of local gradients is exposed during the optimization (Theorem 1). (2) Compared to differential privacy mechanism in which privacy decays with the increasing training epochs, the variation introduced to each wklsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘™w_{k}^{l} hides the local gradients throughout the whole training process, and thus retains privacy regardless of the number of training epochs.

6. Case study: Confined Gradient Descent for a N-layer neural network

CGD can be applicable to any machine learning algorithms that use gradient descent for optimization. In this section, we apply it to a N-layer neural network to demonstrate its usability. 7. Experiments

We implement CGD and evaluate its performance of model accuracy. It is implemented using C++, and we use Eigen library (Guennebaud etÂ al., 2010) to handle matrix operations and ZeroMQ library (Hintjens, 2013) for distributed messaging. Our evaluation focuses on the performance of CGD in terms of validation loss and accuracy, and the influence of the factorsÂ (the parameters Î´ğ›¿\delta and Î¼ğœ‡\mu) on its performance.

7.1. Performance Evaluation

We evaluate validation loss and accuracy on two popular benchmark datasets: MNISTÂ  (LeCun and Cortes, 2010) and CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009). We compare CGD with the training on aggregated dataÂ (referred to as the centralized training), the training on each participantâ€™s local data onlyÂ (referred to as the local training), and FL with differential privacyÂ (referred to as the DP-FL). CGD is expected to outperform the local training and DP-FL, and approach that of the centralized training. The settings of all trainings are listed below.

  • â€¢

    CGD training. The model is trained using Algorithm 1 on the dataset which is partitioned and distributed to mğ‘šm participants, where m=(mhÃ—mv)ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘šâ„superscriptğ‘šğ‘£m=(m^{h}\times m^{v}). We observe that the performance of all confined models are proximal, and thus we report the worst performance in this section.

  • â€¢

    Centralized trainingÂ (the baseline). We take the performance of centralized training as the baseline. In this setting, the training is on the entire dataset using the batch update.

  • â€¢

    Local training. In this setting, the data and model are distributed to mğ‘šm participants in the same way as in CGD. Each participant separately trains their local models from their local data, without sharing the gradients.

  • â€¢

    DP-FL. We take the scheme proposed by Abadi et al.Â (Abadi etÂ al., 2016b), one of the state-of-the-art differentially private FL schemes, in our experiments. Due to the different setting of network architecture and hyper-parameters, its centralized baseline is slightly different from ours. Therefore, we report the margin between its performance and the performance of its baseline.

7.1.1. MNIST

Our first set of experiments are conducted on the standard MNIST dataset which is a benchmark for handwritten digit recognition. It has 60,0006000060,000 training samples and 10,0001000010,000 test samples, each with 784784784 features representing 28Ã—28282828\times 28 pixels in the image. We use a fully-connect neural network (FNN) with ReLU of 256256256 units and softmax of 10 classes with cross-entropy loss.

We conduct our experiments with CGDâ€™s default settings:

  • â€¢

    Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0, leading to a fixed learning rate which is in line with most machine learning algorithms,

  • â€¢

    Î´=0.1ğ›¿0.1\delta=0.1 (cf. Equation 11), and

  • â€¢

    the standard weight initialization scheme based on the Gaussian distribution of mean 0 and variance 1.

Figure 4 summarizes the performance with varying number of participants. In general, CGD stays close to the centralized baseline in both validation loss and accuracy, and as expected, significantly outperforms the local training. In the worst case of m=(1000Ã—112)ğ‘š1000112m=(1000\times 112) when CGD contains the greatest number of participants, i.e., each participant owns a small proportion consisting of 606060 samples with 777 features, CGD still achieves 0.2090.2090.209 and 93.74%percent93.7493.74\% in validation loss and accuracy respectively, close to 0.0810.0810.081 and 97.54%percent97.5497.54\% of the centralized baseline. In contrast, the performance of local training declines to 2.3482.3482.348 and 11.64%percent11.6411.64\%. TableÂ 3 lists the detailed performance comparison with both centralized and local trainings, and TableÂ 4 lists the comparison with DP-FL. More results are given with varying number of participants in Appendix C (Figure 9 and Table 8).

7.1.2. CIFAR-10

Our second set of experiments are conducted on the CIFAR-10 dataset. It consists of 60000 32Ã—32323232\times 32 colour images in 10 classes (e.g., airplane, bird, and cat), with 6000 images per class. The images are divided into 50000 training images and 10000 test images. We use the ResNet-56 architecture proposed by He et al.Â (He etÂ al., 2016). It takes as input images of size 32Ã—32323232\times 32, with the per-pixel mean subtracted. Its first layer is 3Ã—3333\times 3 convolutions, and then a stack of 3Ã—183183\times 18 layers is used, with 3Ã—3333\times 3 convolutions of filter sizes {32,16,8}32168\{32,16,8\} respectively, and 181818 layers for each filter size. The numbers of filters are {16,32,64}163264\{16,32,64\} in each stack. The network ends with an average pooling layer, a fully-connected (FC) layer with 102410241024 units, and softmax. Our training data augmentation follows the setting inÂ (He etÂ al., 2016). For each training image, we generate a new distorted image by randomly flipping the image horizontally with probability 0.50.50.5, and adding 4 amounts of padding to all sides before cropping the image to the size of 32Ã—32323232\times 32.

Since our focus is on evaluating the proposed CGD, rather than enhancing the state-of-the-art analysis on CIFAR-10, we utilize the transferability222Transfer learning allows the analyst to take a model trained on one dataset and transfer it to another without retrainingÂ (Shin etÂ al., 2016). of convolutional layers to save the computational cost of computing per-example gradients. We follow the experiment setting of Abadi et al.Â (Abadi etÂ al., 2016b), which treats the CIFAR-10 as the private dataset and CIFAR-100 as a public dataset. CIFAR-100 has the same image types as CIFAR-10, and it has 100 classes containing 600 images each. We use CIFAR-100 to train a network with the aforementioned architecture, and freeze the parameters of the convolutional layers and retrain only the last FC layer on CIFAR-10.

Training on the entire dataset with batch update reaches the validation accuracy of 75.75%percent75.7575.75\%, which is taken as our centralized training baseline333We note that by making the network deeper or using other advanced techniques, better accuracy can be obtained, with the state-of-the-art being about 99.37%Â (Kolesnikov etÂ al., 2019).. For the CGD training, each participant feeds the pre-trained convolutional layers with their private data partitions, generates the input features to the FC layer, and randomly initializes the confined model parameters of the FC layer. They then take the input to the FC layer as the private local training data, and train a model using Algorithm 1 with Î´=0.01ğ›¿0.01\delta=0.01 and T=6000ğ‘‡6000T=6000.

Figure 5 and Table 5 summarize our experimental results against centralized training and local training. The results on the validation loss and accuracy are generally in line with that on the MNIST dataset. In the worst case of m=(1000Ã—32)ğ‘š100032m=(1000\times 32), CGD achieves 0.7240.7240.724 and 74.29%percent74.2974.29\% in validation loss and accuracy respectively, which are relatively near to the centralized baselineÂ (0.6750.6750.675 and 75.72%percent75.7275.72\%). TableÂ 6 summarize the results against DP-FL. In line with the results on MNIST, the accuracy difference to the centralized baseline in CGD is smaller than that in DP-FL.

7.2. Influencing Factors of CGD

In this section, we study the influence of initialization and the parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu on CGD performance. This study is conducted with the MNIST dataset.

7.2.1. Role of the initialization

According to Theorem 1, the gap between CGD solution and the centralized model is bounded by Ïµ=mâ€‹â€–ğ”¼jâˆˆm(w1lâˆ’w1j)â€–italic-Ïµğ‘šnormsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘—ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘—\epsilon=m\|\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{j\in m}(w_{1}^{l}-w_{1}^{j})\|, in which each w1lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘™w_{1}^{l} is decided by Î´ğ›¿\delta in Equation 11. Therefore, we investigate how the initialization setting affects CGDâ€™s performance.

To this end, we conduct two experiments in which we mutate parameter Î´ğ›¿\delta while keeping other settings unchangingÂ (i.e., Î¼=0ğœ‡0\mu=0 and T=2000ğ‘‡2000T=2000). In the first experiment, we let all participants use the same Î´ğ›¿\delta in {0.1,0.06,0.01,0.001}0.10.060.010.001\{0.1,0.06,0.01,0.001\}, as they are around 160000160000\frac{1}{\sqrt{60000}}Â (recall that 600006000060000 is the sample size of MNIST). In the other experiment, we let each participant randomly select its own Î´ğ›¿\delta based on the uniform distribution within the range from 0.0010.0010.001 to 0.10.10.1.

The results of our first experiment are shown in FigureÂ 6 and the first five columns in TableÂ 7. In general, as Î´ğ›¿\delta decreases, CGD achieves better performance. This confirms our expectation: decreasing Î´ğ›¿\delta would reduce the value of â€–ğ”¼jâˆˆmh(w1lâˆ’w1j)â€–normsubscriptğ”¼ğ‘—superscriptğ‘šâ„superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘—\|\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{j\in m^{h}}(w_{1}^{l}-w_{1}^{j})\|, such that the confined models are closer to the centralized optimum. We have not observed significant difference from Î´=0.1ğ›¿0.1\delta=0.1, 0.060.060.06 and 0.010.010.01. In the case of m=(1000Ã—112)ğ‘š1000112m=(1000\times 112), the validation accuracy and loss achieve 97.08%percent97.0897.08\% and 0.0960.0960.096 with Î´=0.01ğ›¿0.01\delta=0.01 which outperform 93.74%percent93.7493.74\% and 0.2090.2090.209 in the setting of Î´=0.1ğ›¿0.1\delta=0.1, but both are close to the centralized model whose validation accuracy and loss are 97.61%percent97.6197.61\% and 0.0780.0780.078 respectively. However, Î´ğ›¿\delta cannot be set too small, in order to maintain numerical stability in neural networkÂ (Glorot and Bengio, 2010). For example, when we lower Î´ğ›¿\delta to 0.0010.0010.001, the performance starts decreasing.

The results of our second experiment are shown in Figure 7 and the last column in TableÂ 7. When the participants uniformly randomize their Î´ğ›¿\deltas from 0.0010.0010.001 to 0.10.10.1, the performance of CGD is still comparable with the centralized mode. For example, with m=(1000Ã—112)ğ‘š1000112m=(1000\times 112) participants, CGD achieves 95.82%percent95.8295.82\% and 0.1360.1360.136 in the validation accuracy and loss. This suggests that CGD keeps robust when the Î´ğ›¿\deltas of its participants differ by two orders of magnitude.

7.2.2. Effect of the parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu

According to Theorem 1, the convergence speed of CGD is affected by the parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu. We thus conduct an experiment to investigate this relation. In this experiment, we tune Î¼ğœ‡\mu while keeping Î´ğ›¿\delta fixed as 0.10.10.1. For the stepsizeÂ (Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k}), we run CGD with a fixed Î±ğ›¼\alpha till it (approximately) reaches a preferred point, and then continue our experiment with Î±1=Î±subscriptğ›¼1ğ›¼\alpha_{1}=\alpha. This is to keep CGD practical, as each time the stepsize is diminished, more iterations are required. Therefore, the first 600060006000 iterations is run with Î±=0.01ğ›¼0.01\alpha=0.01, and then diminish Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k} in each of the following 800080008000 iterations.

Figure 8 demonstrates the results with varying Î¼ğœ‡\mu for m=(100Ã—49)ğ‘š10049m=(100\times 49) and m=(1000Ã—112)ğ‘š1000112m=(1000\times 112). For the case of m=(100Ã—49)ğ‘š10049m=(100\times 49), Î¼â‰¥0.01ğœ‡0.01\mu\geq 0.01 gives a slightly faster speed. CGD reaches the validation accuracy of 95.9%percent95.995.9\% at 11401tâ€‹hsuperscript11401ğ‘¡â„11401^{th} iteration, 234023402340 iterationsÂ (16.7% less) faster than training with Î¼<0.01ğœ‡0.01\mu<0.01. For the case of m=1000Ã—112)m=1000\times 112), Î¼>0.05ğœ‡0.05\mu>0.05 gives a faster speed. CGD reaches the validation accuracy 95.68%percent95.6895.68\% at 11821tâ€‹hsuperscript11821ğ‘¡â„11821^{th} iteration, 214021402140 iterationsÂ (15.28% less) faster than training with Î¼â‰¤0.05ğœ‡0.05\mu\leq 0.05. Even though such slight difference is observed, our experiment suggests that the effect of tuning Î¼ğœ‡\mu is relatively limited. The gain of the validation accuracy is only within 0.2%percent0.20.2\% in the cost of around 200020002000 iterations.

8. Conclusion

We have presented CGD, a novel optimization algorithm for learning confined models to enhance privacy for federated learning. Privacy preservation is achieved against an honest-but-curious adversary even though the majority (mâˆ’2ğ‘š2m-2 out of mğ‘šm) of participants are corrupted. We formally proved the convergence of CGD optimization. In our experiments, we achieved validation accuracy of 97.01% with (1000Ã—11210001121000\times 112) participants on the MNIST dataset, and 74.4% with (1000Ã—321000321000\times 32) participants on the CIFAR-10 dataset. Both are comparable to the performance of centralized training.

A number of future work directions are of interest. In particular, we see new research opportunities in applying our techniques to asynchronous FL, allowing different participants to be at different iterations of model updates up to a bounded delay. We are also considering other types of deep networks, for example, unsupervised neural networks such as autoencoders.

Appendix A Additive secret sharing scheme

Secret sharing schemes aim to securely distribute secret values amongst a group of participants. Appendix B Simulation Paradigm

In simulation paradigm (a.k.a., the real/ideal model)Â (Goldreich etÂ al., 2019), the security of a protocol is proved by comparing what an adversary can do in a real protocol execution to what it can do in an ideal scenario, which is secure by definition. Formally, a protocol ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} securely computes a functionality â„±psubscriptâ„±ğ‘\mathcal{F}_{p}, if for every adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} in the real model, there exists an adversary ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} in the ideal model, such that the view of the adversary from a real execution ğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathit{VIEW_{real}} is indistinguishable from the view of the adversary from an ideal execution ğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}}. The adversary ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} in the ideal model, is called the simulator. An indistinguishability between ğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathit{VIEW_{real}} and ğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}} guarantees that the adversary can learn nothing more than their own inputs and the information required by ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} for the simulation. In other words, the information required by ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} for the simulation is the only information that can leak to adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} from the real execution.

Let cğ‘c denote the set of corrupted parties. The simulator performs the following operations:

  • â€¢

    Generate dummy inputs {Î·l}superscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\{\eta^{l}\} for each honest party lâˆ‰cğ‘™ğ‘l\notin c and receives the actual inputs {xl}superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™\{x^{l}\} of corrupted parties lâˆˆcğ‘™ğ‘l\in c;

  • â€¢

    Run ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} over {Î·l}superscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\{\eta^{l}\} (lâˆ‰cğ‘™ğ‘l\notin c ) and {xl}superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™\{x^{l}\} (lâˆˆcğ‘™ğ‘l\in c) and add all messages sent/received by corrupted parties to ğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}};

    Send the inputs of corrupted parties {xl}superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™\{x^{l}\} (lâˆˆcğ‘™ğ‘l\in c) to the trusted third party;

  • â€¢

    Receive the outputs of corrupted users {yl}superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘™\{y^{l}\} (lâˆˆcğ‘™ğ‘l\in c) from the trusted third party and add them to ğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}}.

Meanwhile, a real instance of ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} is executed with actual inputs for all parties, and ğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathit{VIEW_{real}} is created by gathering inputs of corrupted parties, messages sent/received by corrupted parties during the protocol and their final outputs.
